content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> </math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>x</mi> </math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </math> is a real number. The graphs of the functions <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> are shown in the figure for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>0</mn> <mo>≤</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>≤</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. It is known that <math alttext="g of x equals, the fraction with numerator 12, and denominator 3 plus x, end fraction " overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>12</mn> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> <mo>+</mo> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> for <math alttext="x is greater than or equal to 0" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>≥</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. The twice-differentiable function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, which is not explicitly given, satisfies <math alttext="f of 3 equals 2" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>3</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 3, of, f of x, d x, equals 10" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mrow> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </msubsup> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mo>ⅆ</mo> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>10</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. (a) Find the area of the shaded region enclosed by the graphs of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> </math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>x</mi> </math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </math> is a real number. The graphs of the functions <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> are shown in the figure for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 3" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>0</mn> <mo>≤</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>≤</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. It is known that <math alttext="g of x equals, the fraction with numerator 12, and denominator 3 plus x, end fraction " overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mrow> <mn>12</mn> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> <mo>+</mo> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> for <math alttext="x is greater than or equal to 0" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>≥</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. The twice-differentiable function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, which is not explicitly given, satisfies <math alttext="f of 3 equals 2" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>3</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 3, of, f of x, d x, equals 10" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mrow> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </msubsup> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mo>ⅆ</mo> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>10</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. (a) Find the area of the shaded region enclosed by the graphs of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

(b) Evaluate the improper integral <math alttext="the integral from 0 to infinity, of, open parenthesis, g of x, close parenthesis squared, d x" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mrow> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>∞</mi> </mrow> </msubsup> <msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mo>ⅆ</mo> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, or show that the integral diverges.

(c) Let <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>h</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, x times f prime of x" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>h</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo largeop="true">⋅</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>′</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. Find the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 3, of, h of x, d x" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mrow> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </msubsup> <mrow> <mi>h</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mo>ⅆ</mo> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

topic.text: 6.11: (BC ONLY) Integrating Using Integration by Parts

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
